user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemGetInfo(osal_id_t sem_id, OS_bin_sem_prop_t *bin_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(bin_prop);

    memset(bin_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_bin_sem_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_bin_sem_table, token);

        strncpy(bin_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(bin_prop->name) - 1);
        bin_prop->creator = record->creator;
        return_code       = OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl(&token, bin_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_bin_sem_table
...
int32 OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_bin_sem_prop_t *sem_prop)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    /* put the info into the structure */
    sem_prop->value = sem->current_value;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The primary potential sources of unreachable code in this snippet stem from macros or called routines that may not return (e.g. BUGCHECK used by OS_CHECK_POINTER) or from control-flow-dependent blocks (the success branch after OS_ObjectIdGetById). Those specific lines/blocks above are reported for investigation because their reachability depends on the semantics of the macros/callees and build-time configurations.

Other fragments in the provided code do not need investigation for unreachable-code concerns: the variable declarations at the top are inert; the call into OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl and its body (as given) are simple, return OS_SUCCESS, and contain no alternate non-returning paths; the OS_ObjectIdGetById implementation shows explicit returns on failure or success (no obviously unreachable statements within that function as provided); and the macros used to index tables (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken usage) are straightforward address/index computations rather than control-flow constructs. Therefore, beyond the listed fragments which depend on macro/callee semantics, there are no additional candidate unreachable-code fragments in the supplied code to investigate.
